metadata.name: Potential Regsvr32 Commandline Flag Anomaly
metadata.comment: Detects a potential command line flag anomaly related to "regsvr32" in which the "/i" flag is used without the "/n" which should be uncommon.

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM process_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (activity_id = 1 AND endswith(lower(process.name), lower('\\\\regsvr32.exe')) AND (contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' -i:')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' /i:')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' –i:')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' —i:')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' ―i:'))) AND NOT contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' -n ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' /n ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' –n ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' —n ')) OR contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower(' ―n ')))

output.summary: Detects a potential command line flag anomaly related to "regsvr32" in which the "/i" flag is used without the "/n" which should be uncommon.

metadata.objective: False positive: Administrator typo might cause some false positives Reference: https://twitter.com/sbousseaden/status/1282441816986484737?s=12
